docs.lead_paragraph: Talking over lunch this week in the dining room of the American Postal Workers House, a federally subsidized residence for the elderly, 87-year-old Leah Greenstein pulled from her purse a well-worn card on which she keeps a list of her medications. ''I take Synthroid -- that's for my thyroid -- I take two of them,'' she said, reading from the list. ''Prinvil -- that's for high blood pressure -- two a day. Ecotrin -- that's coated aspirin; it doesn't affect the stomach -- to prevent a heart attack or stroke. Prilosec -- that's for digestion. Vioxx -- I just started that a few weeks ago. That's the newest drug for arthritis.'' In all, Mrs. Greenstein, whose ailments include high blood pressure and colitis, takes 12 prescription medicines daily.

headline.main: For Elderly, Pills Are Blessing and Curse

docs.abstract: Many elderly people say paying for prescription drugs and keeping all their pills straight is daily concern; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: After being treated successfully for what doctors called a moderate heart attack, former Mayor Edward I. Koch left the hospital yesterday, wreathed in smiles and trailed by reporters. ''I have no fear of death,'' he said at a news conference beforehand at New York Weill Cornell Center of Presbyterian Hospital, wearing a pale blue shirt and suspenders. ''But I want to go all at once, not slice by slice.''

headline.main: Koch Is Out of Hospital; Beame Is Treated for Pains

docs.abstract: Edward I Koch leaves hospital after treatment for moderate heart attack; photo; former Mayor Abraham D Beame is admitted to hospital with chest pains (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Gearing up for next week's Senate debate on patients' rights to medical care and insurance, President Clinton lambasted Republican leaders today for what he suggested were cynical delaying tactics intended to defeat Democratic efforts to establish minimum Federal standards for health maintenance organizations and insurers. ''They're not for it,'' the President told a sympathetic audience of doctors, nurses and local politicians at the Harbor-U.C.L.A. Medical Center in the southern Los Angeles suburb of Torrance this morning. ''But they know they can't afford to be caught being against it.''

headline.main: Clinton Says G.O.P. Seeks To Avert Vote On H.M.O.'s

docs.lead_paragraph: Few places in America are as impoverished as the Pine Ridge Indian reservation in South Dakota. On Wednesday, President Clinton sat on a dilapidated porch belonging to a woman who had 28 people living in her five bedrooms. He heard about the troubles of a place where the unemployment rate among the Oglala Sioux is 73 percent. The day before, on a sweltering afternoon, he walked through the boarded-up streets of the Mississippi Delta town of Clarksdale. This week Mr. Clinton traveled through some of America's poorest areas, turning attention to communities left out of the prosperity enjoyed by much of the country. Such trips can raise awareness of poverty, often, most importantly, for the politicians themselves. John Kennedy began his anti-poverty programs after being haunted by what he saw while campaigning in West Virginia. Robert Kennedy's visit to the Mississippi Delta in 1967 helped set one of the themes of his Presidential campaign.
docs.abstract: Editorial praises Pres Clinton's visit to some of America's poorest areas, mostly in South, that have been left out of economic prosperity enjoyed by much of country; says such trips can raise awareness of poverty; backs his New Markets Initiative, which would inject $15 billion in new capital into communities; says it is more promising than some previous plans to help depressed areas

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite fears about violence in schools, the number of children committing crimes or being hurt in them has been dropping since 1993, according to an annual Government report on the state of American children that was released today. The report said the situation of children and teen-agers was improving and mostly hopeful, with the numbers of vaccinations and preschool enrollment up while those for teen-age smoking and pregnancies were down.

headline.main: Upbeat Data on Crime and Youth

docs.abstract: Federal Government issues its annual report on state of Ameican children; Federal Interagency Forum on Child and Family Statistics finds that despite fears about violence in schools, number of children committing crimes or being hurt in them has been dropping since 1993 (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Lamenting the life of the Mississippi Delta, racing from an Appalachian hamlet to an inner-city Walgreens, embracing the vast desolation of the land of the Sioux -- these are unusual things for a President to do. They are especially unusual gestures from this President, a self-styled guardian of middle-class interests who has kept a careful distance from the truly down-and-out. For years, old-fashioned liberals have urged President Clinton to embrace the cause of the poor more directly.
docs.abstract: News analysis of Pres Clinton's four-day tour of poverty in America; says his curious tour seems to arouse an equally curious response: indifference, if not outright hostility among his natural allies; photos of Robert F Kennedy during his famous 1967 tour of Mississippi Delta, and Lyndon B Johnson in 1964 as he undertook war on poverty (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: From Port Imperial Boulevard, which parallels the nearly milelong Hudson River waterfront in West New York, N.J., the view is of a changing landscape. What was an industrial wasteland is being reborn as a $700 million residential community, called Port Imperial North, which is to have 4,300 residences on 100 acres hugging the river's edge in this Hudson County town atop the Palisades cliffs across from midtown Manhattan. The development's first rental neighborhood, the Landings, is rising on the northern end of the site, where rail and shipping operations once stood. And though the project is two months away from completion, 35 percent of its 276 one- to three-bedroom apartments have been leased, according to the developer, a partnership between the Roseland Property Company of Roseland, N.J., and the Prudential Insurance Company of America in Newark. The units, many with river views, have 700 to 1,520 square feet of space, and rent for $1,430 to $3,500 a month.

headline.main: Residential Real Estate; A Rental Neighborhood Along the Hudson's Edge

docs.lead_paragraph: N.A.S.D. Fines Prudential $20 Million for Deception In yet another penalty for misleading customers over more than a decade, Prudential Insurance was fined $20 million by the National Association of Securities Dealers, the highest fine ever imposed by the association.

docs.lead_paragraph: Death rates from lung cancer could be greatly reduced if smokers and former smokers were routinely given CAT scans of their lungs, doctors are reporting today. The scans use a new technique that is far more sensitive than conventional chest X-rays and can detect tumors when they are small enough to be cured. Currently, routine chest X-rays and other screening tests for lung cancer are not recommended, even for smokers, because the tests cannot identify tumors early enough to save or even prolong patients' lives.

headline.main: CAT SCAN PROCESS COULD CUT DEATHS FROM LUNG CANCER

docs.abstract: Doctors report that death rates from lung cancer could be greatly reduced if smokers and former smokers were routinely given CAT scans of their lungs; scans use new technique that is far more sensitive than conventional chest X-rays and can detect tumors when they are small enough to be cured; Dr Claudia I Henschke, division chief of chest imaging at Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan, and first author of study, says that using new screening techniques could raise survival rate for lung cancer from 12 percent or 15 percent to 80 percent; Dr John D Minna, lung cancer specialist, praises study for including women, who have been excluded from all previous screening studies (M)
